lines.text: Do you wear that hat in Hamburg?
What's wrong with a cowboy in Hamburg?
Why did you spread this rumor that I am with one foot in the grave?
Remember that day we were introduced at the auction? You said, "I've heard of you." You said that in a very nasty way.
That was all?
Isn't that enough?
What's wrong with you?
I'm confused.
Don't try to be a nice guy.
I want to go home.
Let me love you for your money.
I'm confused!
Close the doors, they'll come in through the windows... A little older, a little more confused.
It's December 6th, 1976. There's nothing to fear but fear itself. I know less and less about who I am, or who anybody else is.
Even this river - this river reminds me of another river.

I like this room. It's got a good feel to it. It's quiet and peaceful. Just like you. I envy you. The smell of paint and wood. Must be good to work here. Then when you finish something, you can see what you've done.
It's not that easy. Not that safe and easy. What do you make?
I make money. And I travel a lot. I'm bringing the Beatles back to Hamburg.
I think you're not a very serious man.

[Hands Derwatt a wad of cash]
I think this is serious. I sold one painting, I'm ready to sell another one.
How much?
That's $2,000 for you. I told you I've got a good eye.
Take care of it. A new one's hard to find.
Don't you think I know that?
Listen. I know rock musicians. I know lawyers. I know art dealers, pimps, politicians. But murder? I don't want to be involved. Period.
Gantner told me you were a good craftsman. I admire that. I've always wanted to be able to make something with my hands. But, well, some people have it and some people don't.
I don't like people who buy paintings as an investment.
Well, you count me out.
No. I count you in.
I would like to be your friend. But friendship isn't possible.
That makes me feel very comfortable.
[first lines]
Who is it?
It's Ripley.
The door is open.
[last lines]
We made it anyway, Jonathan. Be careful.

[singing]
Pity the poor immigrant... whose...
